page.title: 12Landscape & Local History
page.content: Rhu 25/83 & 26/83 A good example of shallow entrance or mouth of a fiord. Before dredging this was too shallow to allow shipping to pass through to Naval Base at Faslane. In years gone by Narrows known as 'The Jumblies' due to the turbulent waters there. 24/83 - block surrounded by sea on 3 sides as Rosneath forms toe of Peninsula. Highland Boundary Fault Line runs through toe. The name Rosneath may be derived from 'Ros' a point and 'Nevydd' a 6th century bishop or 'Neimidh' a sanctuary. Rhu took name from Gaelic 'rudha' meaning promontory. This refers to Rhu Point, a spit formed of shingle. Could be classed as 'Gateway to Highlands'as it lies to n/w of Highland Boundary Fault Line.
